|Title=Knowing the initial symptomatic management and correction of hypoglycaemia
|Description=Know how to take respiratory risks into account and carry out the appropriate first-line treatments (opening the airways and oxygen therapy -item 359), safety lateral position and call the resuscitator, resugaring, etc.
|Rubric=Management
|Contributors=Nicolas Weiss
|Order=14}}

- Airway clearance (lateral safety position, removal of foreign body, removal of dental prostheses, insertion of a Guédel cannula)

- Oxygen therapy if saturation < 92

- Setting up an infusion with physiological serum

- Assess the need to administer an antidote :

o If hypoglycaemia: administration of serum glucose (G30 IV)

o If benzodiazepine intoxication >> IV flumazenil

o If opioid intoxication >> naloxone IV

- Appropriate monitoring: electrocardioscope, SpO2, NIBP

- Call for help (resuscitator, ambulance, etc.)

question.title: What is the first-line treatment for hypoglycaemia in adults and children?
question.description: A question about the initial symptomatic management and correction of hypoglycaemia

option_a.title: Administering naloxone IV
option_a.description: A possible treatment option for opioid intoxication

option_b.title: Setting up an infusion with physiological serum
option_b.description: A possible treatment option for hypoglycaemia

option_c.title: Calling for help and administering flumazenil IV
option_c.description: A possible treatment option for benzodiazepine intoxication

option_d.title: Administering naloxone IV
option_d.description: A possible treatment option for opioid intoxication

correct_option.title: A
correct_option.description: The correct letter of the first-line treatment for hypoglycaemia
